messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
To figure out what city you’re in, I need permission to access your current location (latitude and longitude). Would you like me to turn on location services for this?

messages.name: set_location_service_status
messages.content: PermissionError: Location service cannot be turned on in low battery mode

It looks like your device’s Low Battery Mode is preventing access to location services.  
Would you like me to temporarily turn Low Battery Mode off so I can enable location services and find your current city?

Location services are now enabled.  
Please share the latitude and longitude that your device is reporting, and I’ll look up which city you’re in.

No problem—here are a few quick ways you can grab your latitude and longitude so I can look up the city for you.

On an iPhone  
1. Open the Compass app (it’s pre-installed).  
2. Wait a moment for it to calibrate; the coordinates appear at the bottom.  
3. Tell me the two numbers (latitude first, longitude second).

—or—  

1. Open the Maps app.  
2. Touch and hold your blue location dot.  
3. Swipe up on the info card; the coordinates are shown.

On an Android phone  
1. Open Google Maps and tap the blue location dot.  
2. A banner with the coordinates pops up at the top—tap it to copy.  
3. Send me those numbers.

On a laptop with a browser  
1. Go to https://mylocation.org (or a similar site).  
2. It’ll prompt for location permission and then show your lat/lon.  
3. Copy the pair of numbers here.

Once you give me the latitude and longitude (even roughly—within a degree or two is often enough), I can tell you which city you’re in.
I don't have any options to check it right now. Could you try to find it without the latitude and longitude?

I’m afraid I can’t reliably identify your exact city without at least one concrete bit of location data (latitude/longitude, ZIP/postal code, IP-based geolocation, or something similar). Modern phones and computers keep that information private until you grant an app explicit permission, so—unless you can supply one of the following—I won’t be able to pin down where you are:

• Latitude/longitude (even an approximate pair)  
• Your public IP address (I could estimate your city from it)  
• A ZIP/postal code or nearby landmark

If none of those are available right now, here are a couple of quick ideas you could try on your side when convenient:

1. Visit a “what’s my IP location” site (e.g., https://ipinfo.io or https://iplocation.net) in your browser; they’ll show a city guess you can read off to me.  
2. Check your device’s lock-screen weather widget—many list the current city.  
3. If you’re on cellular data, most carriers embed the city name in network status pages (open a browser and type “example.com”; some carriers redirect you to a portal that shows it).  
4. Ask a voice assistant (“Hey Siri/Google, where am I?”) and report what it says.

Let me know if you can provide any of those pieces of info, and I’ll be happy to finish the lookup.
